Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2019 03:50PM sflow wrote: I suppose I was lucky. I told my dermatologist about being a survivor of IDC in other breast & had a rash on other nipple. She said she could give me a cream or a punch biopsy. I opted for the biopsy. I don’t have results yet but feel relieved I got test done.
Posts.Title: left nipple itchy concern ( last almost 2 months already) mtl114 sflow

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 11:52AM sflow wrote: Hi--I had an oncotype of 22--my onc also left it up to me.  As a widowed single parent, I did not feel I could tolerate the rigors or chemo and expect my sons to fend for themselves. Also, there is heart disease rampant in my family and did not want to risk the chemo. I was 56 at time of diagnosis.  My onc said I would derive 1% benefit from chemo.  I am close to 5 yrs out and pray everyday for continued good health.  It's just a crap shoot as far as I am concerned.
Posts.Title: Chemo - since I have a choice, why would I? BobbiMarie Lee7

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 02:56PM sflow wrote: I would tell the gyn the term used by the surgeon and tell her of your concerns.  I am guessing that surgeon was somewhat incompetent or your gyn would have followed up with you on that diagnosis.

Posts.Content: sflow wrote: I am one yr out of lumpectomy surgery.  My doctor sends me for scans every 6 months.  All results are good, but he said I have something on my gallbladder that could be a stone, polyp or sludge.  Can any of this be pre-cancer?  Also, was reviewing my old path report and said my tumor was "solid type"--what does this mean?  Is it considered more aggressive? Dx 11/15/2006, IDC, Right, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- (IHC) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: test results and questions sflow leaf

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2012 03:52PM sflow wrote: Please try not to get yourself worked up to think the worst.  Yes, the waiting is insane and the anxiety awful, but you will eventually find out some kind of news.  I hope it is nothing, but if it turns out to be cancer, you will get a plan in place and take things a little bit at a time.  I received my biopsy results in 2 days--it was not good news, but I had a good hard cry and moved on like so many brave peple on this site have.  We are all here for you to listen and pray and advise as well as possible.  If necessary, call your PCP to give you something to take the edge off your anxiety.
Posts.Title: Scared kmatt OhiaLehua

Posts.Content: sflow wrote: I had a bone scan 2 hrs ago and was found to have Osteopoenia.  2 months later I was diagnosed with IDC.  After lumpectomy and radiation, my doctor put me on Arimidex.  Fearful for my bones, I asked him to put me on something to counteract the negative effects of the aromatase inhibitor   I have been on Evista about 18 months and just had another bone scan. I am happy to say, there has been an improvement in my bone density.  Don't know if it is the Evista, calcium or almost daily walks that have helped, but that was good news to me.  Now on to the onc in 2 weeks and more lovely scans to stress over. Dx 11/15/2006, IDC, Right, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- (IHC) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bone Scan sflow AnneW

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2011 04:48AM sflow wrote: Like many people will tell you, you are at the worst part.  Waiting makes anyone crazy.  Soon you will have results and will get a good treatment plan in place.  We will all hope and pray for the best for you.  Try to keep busy so your mind is not obsessed with this.

Best wishes to you!

I tend to believe things are improving in the advances in BC treatments.

Posts.Content: sflow wrote: I am a 12 year survivor of Stage 1 IDC. I have posted off & on the last few weeks of new symptoms on healthy breast. These included soreness & burning pain & slight rash on Areola. Mammogram was clear but it wasn’t feeling better. My sweet dermatologist knew my fears & immediately did a punch biopsy. It was a long wait for results due to special staining for Pagets. I am happy to report results were benign. I feel like I dodged a bullet. Thank you to all people who offered support Dx 11/15/2006, IDC, Right, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- (IHC) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 07:10PM sflow wrote: I had my first screening colonoscopy about 6 yrs ago.  I am an early stage IDC survivor of 4 1/2 yrs.  Last year I was having some heart burn and was told to have another colonoscopy.  A tiny polyp was found--it was not cancerous or even pre-cancerous.  The doctor told me I have to have a colonoscopy every 3 yrs now--no family history of any kind of cancer.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2010 04:41PM sflow wrote: Hi, I had a thyroid nodule years before my breast cancer diagnosis.  I work with an endocrinologist who says it is over 3cm and is cystic.  I have had it biopsied twice and have an ultrasound on it every year to check for changes--have seen none yet--knock on wood.  My endo also tests my blood periodically, but no thyroid problems.  Supposedly the nodules are very very common.

Posts.Title: Can't stop worrying and googling ls1229 Cat123

Posts.Content: sflow wrote: I have had a nodule on my thyroid for a few years.I had a lot of tests cause I had rad treatments as a child. It was biopsied about 3 yrs ago and found to be just cystic. Then I was diagnosed with IDC in 06 and underwent 38 radiation treatments. Now my thyroid nodule has grown .2 centimeters. I am to undergo another biopsy on it and am frightened. Anyone experience anything like this? If it were cancer again, would it be a new primary, metastis or caused by the radiation treatments? I know this is hard to answer, but would appreciate talking to anyone in a similar circumstance. Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2009 02:21PM sflow wrote: Just a suggestion, but you might post your question to Lillian Shockney--just look on the homepage.  She is an oncological nurse and 2 time BC survivor and very knowledgeable.  She also has an "ask the expert" column at the Johns Hopkins BC website, but she only answers questions on there periodically.  I hope you get some answers.  The wait and lack of knowledge are stressful. My best to you Sandi
Posts.Title: Pathology Back....Help Needed layla26 Polyana

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 02:54AM sflow wrote: Best wishes to you.  It sounds like you have prepared yourself mentally and have lived a good clean life.  Do not waste your energy pondering what could have brought this on--you need to focus on getting good care and taking care of yourself and your children.  You will be in my thoughts and prayers.
Posts.Title: I don't think I've ever been this sad teeballmom adenacb

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2011 12:36PM sflow wrote: I had it twice and it is very serious.  It scared me cause it was on the breast where I had IDC previously and I thought it might be IBC,  It looked like half a red tank top running from my collar bone to my tummy.  The first time my PCP thought it was the result of a sinus infection and gave me an antibiotic.  It went away from about 2 months and came right back.  That time, I went to my oncologist.  He flipped out and wanted to put me in the hospital on IV antibiotics.  Fortunately, he was able to give me a strong antibiotic and it went away.  It did take a while for the redness to disappear.  In fact, he had me come in for a re-check and gave me another dose "just in case".  It is not something to mess with!
Posts.Title: cellulitis jinky sushanna1

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2012 07:11PM sflow wrote: Weight watchers is best.  It takes about 3 weeks before you see results, but it is worth it.  Hard work and planning but it is endorsed by most doctors.

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2011 03:19AM sflow wrote: Good luck, Jessica.  I am almost 5 yrs out.  My onc did all scans and blood tests for me every 6 months.  Now I will see him yearly and only have blood tests done unless I have symptoms.  My onc is very very thorough as I understand the standard of care is not to do the scans for 5 yrs unless there is a problem.  I feel safer having them done, but I do concern myself about the radiation exposure.  Best wishes to you.
